user.speaker: user
user.text: How many types does it offer?

agent.speaker: agent
agent.text:
When you sign up with IBM Cloud®, you will be given a Pay-As-You-Go account. While you need to provide your credit card details for security and identity verification, you can still enjoy using IBM Cloud for free by choosing products from the catalog that have Free and Lite pricing plans. Another account option is the Subscription account, which offers many of the same features as the Pay-As-You-Go account, along with discounts for platform services and consistent billing through subscriptions. Educational institutions may want to provide IBM Cloud accounts to their students so they can gain practical skills by working on projects that utilize IBM Cloud services. For these institutions, such as traditional universities or online learning platforms, it is possible to group accounts by department or subject area and create accounts for each course.
Within each account, students can create resources to develop their projects and collaborate with their peers in the same account. The university will have a comprehensive view of the costs associated with each department and course.

contexts.text:
Account types 

When you register with IBM Cloud®, you are set up with a Pay-As-You-Go account. Even though you provide your credit card information for account security and identity verification purposes, you can still use IBM Cloud for free by selecting products in the catalog that offer Free and Lite pricing plans. Another account type, called a Subscription account, is also available. With a Subscription account, you get many of the same features of a Pay-As-You-Go account, plus discounts for platform services and support with a more consistent billing structure that uses subscriptions.



 Comparing accounts 

The following table provides a comparison of Trial, Pay-As-You-Go, and Subscription accounts. For more details about each account, see the sections that follow.



Table 1. Comparison of IBM Cloud accounts
This table has row and column headers. The row headers identify the feature. The column headers identify the account type. To understand which features apply to the account types, navigate to the row, and find the feature that you're interested in.

 Trial Pay-As-You-Go Subscription 

 [Free community buildpacks](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/cloud-foundry-public?topic=cloud-foundry-public-available_buildpacks) 186 GBH 186 GBH 186 GBH 
 Access to [Lite service plans](https://cloud.ibm.com/catalog/?search=label:lite) ![Feature available](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs-content/v1/content/4d8c6eec891cff72b666dc24bd3211810c77fb42/icons/icon_enabled.svg) ![Feature available](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs-content/v1/content/4d8c6eec891cff72b666dc24bd3211810c77fb42/icons/icon_enabled.svg) !

Educational institutions might want to provide IBM Cloud accounts to their students so that they can learn valuable skills through hands-on projects that use IBM Cloud services. For these institutions, such as traditional universities or online learning platforms, you can group accounts by department or subject area, then create accounts for each course.

Within each account, students can create resources to build their projects and collaborate with other students in the account. The university has a complete view of the costs of each department and course.

Zoom

![A three-tier enterprise that models how a university can organize their accounts. For example, account groups are named for each department: Data Science, Computer Science, and Computer Engineering. Each account group contains individual accounts for each class, such as DS101 and DS102.](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs-content/v1/content/d4595e5202a9a27767cf034e81b038cdf772e0d5/secure-enterprise/images/enterprise-edu.svg)

Figure 6. An enterprise for a university

agent.original_text: The Lite plan is a single type of pricing plan that offers a free service with usage quotas. It allows you to develop an app without any charges and is available with all account types in IBM Cloud. Each service can have one instance of a Lite plan.

llm_based_tags.reasoning: The pronoun 'it' has no clear referent in the query. Without knowing what 'it' refers to (a product, service, system, etc.), the query cannot be understood or answered. This is a classic context-dependent query requiring conversation history.
